div1.p: Carter agrees that algae chara is not particularly effective in the prevention of breeding and offers his assistance in locating a copy of a report Barber needs for his work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to M. A. Barber, September 23, 1923
div1.p:
I am well enough to go home now, but will not go, I presume, until
Wednesday or Thursday.

I note what you say about Chara. We have quite a number of obser-
vations on the presence or absence of Anopheles with various aquatic
plants. I have not been able to satisfy myself, however that this is in
any wise dependent on any chemical given off by the plant. Some cover
the water so closely that they will not oviposit: some grow straight and
thin and give no protection against fish: some grow in bottom that, on
the slightest disturbance makes a “roily” water some rot very quickly--con-
suming the oxygen in the water and hence causes a scum of anerobic organ-
isms or makes it foul.

The above are the only ways which I can now recollect in which Ano-
pheles breeding is affected by aquatic plants--some plus and some minus--
and a knowledge of these plants, while it will tell one where to look for
larvae, or save him much useless dipping, is, I think, of no value in the
the
-2-
prevention of breeding. There are, of course, some plants which greatly
favor breeding, mainly, of course, by protecting against fish and wave
action and I am not disappointed in chara, though I wish it had turned
out differently.

When I get back to Washington, I will try to find the Palestine
report. I suspect I could get a copy of it by writing to Kligler through
the I. H. B. or maybe directly to the American Zionists, for whom I did a
samll amount of work in consultation for the malaria control in Palestine
and, of course, will do so. If the worst comes to the worst, I could
copy the one that Dr. L. O. Howard has in Washington.

If Theodore Hayne is still with you, give him my love and
best wishes for his future. He really is a very fine fellow.

I much wish that this attack (angina pectoris) could have post-
poned itself for a couple of years, but it is far better than if it had come
two years earlier.
Hoping to see you in Washington in November.
div1.closer: Sincerely your friend, (Signed) H. R. Carter. Dictoated, but not read.
